channel.title: Regex
channel.description: Is there any way to search for two characters at once? I know there are predefined classes, but I only need to look for + and -. I can't use /p{Punct}, because I'm using other forms of punctuation. I tried doing \\+\\- and all sorts of variations just to try it and nothing worked, does anyone know if this is possible and or how to do this? Specifically what I'm trying to do is parse in an equation like x^(3) + 2X^(2) - 3X - 4 for all the constants and exponents and such, so I'm starting by getting each term, then I'll go down to parenthesis for exponents, then I'll go for coefficients.

item.title: Regex
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:3, topic:477537”]Do you mean the two characters one after the other, or one or the other? The the latter case, you can just do [\x2b\x2d], where 2b is hex for + and 2d is hex for -. [] is an OR capture group, which is the equivalent to a standard capture group with each element separated by a | (or binary operator).

[abc] is the same as (a|b|c)

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html is tremendously helpful.[/quote]

Wow, I was actually looking at that, but couldn’t figure out that I could use that operator with the symbols. Thanks!

Read full topic

item.title: Regex
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Do you mean the two characters one after the other, or one or the other? The the latter case, you can just do [\x2b\x2d], where 2b is hex for + and 2d is hex for -. [] is an OR capture group, which is the equivalent to a standard capture group with each element separated by a | (or binary operator).

[abc] is the same as (a|b|c)

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html is tremendously helpful.

Read full topic

item.title: Regex

item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

Is there any way to search for two characters at once? I know there are predefined classes, but I only need to look for + and -. I can’t use /p{Punct}, because I’m using other forms of punctuation. I tried doing \+\- and all sorts of variations just to try it and nothing worked, does anyone know if this is possible and or how to do this? Specifically what I’m trying to do is parse in an equation like x^(3) + 2X^(2) - 3X - 4 for all the constants and exponents and such, so I’m starting by getting each term, then I’ll go down to parenthesis for exponents, then I’ll go for coefficients.
